comments.commentBody: I was going to suggest the exact same thing! In my neighborhood in Greenpoint there are cat houses where they are fed and I haven't seen a single rat in the neighborhood (alive at least) in years. As long as they are neutered, the city won't develop a cat problem, and can stop using toxic poisons and ineffective traps.

See the above about coyotes. I also have owls that make their home around my house and yard. I hear them frequently at night. One even perches on my side porch as evidenced by the pellets left there. Bottom line is we are going to always have rats.

@GreatScott: Great, then we can have feral cats roaming the city, darting in front of cars, digging up flower beds, urinating and defecating in people's yards, making noise at night, leaving rat and bird carcasses lying around the sidewalks ... and then it would still be unlikely that the cats would even catch more than a few rats who happen to be on the surface. No thanks, I actually prefer the status quo!

Black and white school children with similar infractions are disciplined differently. There are reports of black kindergarteners who have been expelled from school for haggling over a book or pushing back at a bully on the playground

"South Carolina State Representative William Chumley gave a disturbing interview in which he basically blamed the victims of the white supremacist massacre at Charleston’s Emanuel AME church on the victims. The interview conducted by CNN reporter Drew Griffin was bizarre and alarming all at once."

http://www.rimaregas.com/2015/06/southern-madness-white-confederate-igno...

Then let's go back to 1876, and those more than 3000 African-Americans murdered by right-wing terrorists from 1877-1955.

Convenient how right wing trash always wants people to forget how violent they really are by wanting to cherry-pick the data to exclude how violent they are.

Studies done on the reading of resumes from job applicants -- comparing those with "black sounding" names against those same resumes with "white sounding names" or no names have concluded that racial bias exists in hiring even at the earliest screening stage.
Indeed. What's prevalent is a complete lack of knowledge of the history behind the symbols. Instead, there's lots of bandwagon jumping, sensationalism and hypocrisy.

Yes, symbols are important. The problem in the United States is that symbolism is so elevated that too often it substitutes for real action, as Charles indicates in his last paragraph. Clamoring against the Confederate flag has suddenly become very easy for politicians to do, otherwise you would not see so many of them turning on a dime to do so.

Much of institutional racism is conflated with economic policies that increasingly redistribute wealth and income upwards. I'm struck by how the Confederate flag has drowned out of our media and the public consciousness the much weightier matter of the TPP, which just advanced further through Congress with hardly anyone paying attention. If it eventually passes, it threatens to worsen the wealth and income gap in the US and globally. Obviously, President Obama doesn't see it this way, but it will be ironic if he signs into law a measure that will, I believe, only aggravate our class and race divisions.

It's an especially trenchant point because Mr. Cuomo promised to work toward that goal as a condition for winning the Working Families Party's endorsement over Zephyr Teachout. It was a pledge he started backing away from the very day after he received that endorsement and ultimately reneged altogether.
So what is worse, a Democrat who works to support a Democratic legislature, or one who promises to do so and reneges?
Answer: Mr. DeBlasio is a Democrat and Mr. Chomp is something else entirely.

"In some ways, Mr. de Blasio may need to heed a similar lesson. He antagonized Republican leaders in the Senate by aggressively trying to unseat their members in last year’s elections…"

Why was that was a bad thing to do? (Granted, better it should have been successful).

It *should* address public health concerns. Which means that garbage collection *should* be under its direct purview. If the city won't collect commercial garbage, then it needs to regulate that collection more aggressively, and thus businesses would have to pay more money for more frequent and robust collection.
Incidentally, this would increase the cost of goods and services.
513610 - Your solutions 1, 2, & 3 sound a lot like "broken windows." They will never work in NYC, not anymore!

BigGT
I have a few thoughts on this subject as it is one of my pet peeves.
1. No food on the subways. Fine anyone eating or drinking on the trains or stations.
2. Fines for littering ANYWHERE in public should be heavy. However, most of our garbage pails are outdated and inadequate. Replace them with larger cans that aren't wire mesh.
3. Ticket and fine people who feed the pigeons as that food (usually bread or seeds) draws rats and mice. Moreover, the pigeons usually end up perching on window ledges and defecating there, thus posing another serious health hazard.
In that vane, our west 13 street block has a woman who constantly feeds the pigeons, but numerous complaints by block residents to the police, community board 2 and our local councilperson have been to no avail. This despite the fact that we do have a rat and mice problem on our block.
No contest. Humans.
There are so many paradoxes in life that I have become skeptical about everything.  The rats spread disease; but so do humans.  Who's to say which party is the worst varmint?

People who take the scriptures seriously have to read them carefully, especially when they appear to be contradictory, and not to read selectively. Believers are enjoined to obey the laws of the land UNLESS they violate God's laws. Then they are expected to follow God and not the regulations of humans. There is abundant evidence of and precedent for disobeying unjust governments [ask the civil rights preachers].
I think this is how those resisting certain proposed laws are thinking.

Rick Scarborough, a conservative Christian Nacogdoches, Tex. pastor (ex), said 50,000 pastors and church members signed a petition to SCOTUS that they would consider a law recognizing same-sex marriage an “unjust law.”

But, what about the scriptures that require Christians to submit to the laws of man?

“If they change the playing field and make what we do out of bounds, we will disobey; we will disrespect this decision,” Mr. Scarborough said in an interview.

"Romans 13: 1 - 5

1 Everyone must submit himself to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which God has established. The authorities that exist have been established by God. 2 Consequently, he who rebels against the authority is rebelling against what God has instituted, and those who do so will bring judgment on themselves. 3 For rulers hold no terror for those who do right, but for those who do wrong. Do you want to be free from fear of the one in authority? Then do what is right and he will commend you. 4 For he is God's servant to do you good. But if you do wrong, be afraid, for he does not bear the sword for nothing. He is God's servant, an agent of wrath to bring punishment on the wrongdoer. 5 Therefore, it is necessary to submit to the authorities, not only because of possible punishment but also because of conscience.”

As we can see from this example, when the rules they are supposed to follow go against what they really want to do, they lie and make up their own rules instead.
Next to accessible garbage, selling, eating and disposing of food outdoors contributes significantly to the rat population. Chicago's ban on street food definitely helps keep the population down.
Not a good idea unless and until the city stops using poison to kill rats. There are other innate ratter breeds of dogs that could also be used, but Jack Russell's are the best.

Ron, a friend and neighbor in the East Village has a small dog, a mixed breed quite like a Jack Russell, who is so well trained that she barely needs a leash, but when Rob takes her on a walk to Tompkins Square park, the dog takes off after rats, catching and killing them with one vigorous shake that breaks their necks. If the city encouraged terrier owners to let their fogs hunt, I think this would be a huge help in controlling the rat population.

YES! I moved to Manhattan two years ago and still can't get over the fact that we are not permitted to have garbage disposals. It's absolutely unsanitary, not to mention wasteful to use so many plastic bags. But I won't let sit and take the trash out every day. This really needs to be addressed.
The rats easily go in and out of the dumpsters in the alleys of Chicago

Stop and frisk; search and seizure; broken windows policing....white kid in Texas mows down five people when driving while drunk, judge lets him off, because he "suffers from affluenza " and would not survive prison. Need more?

It could be a fitting end , since these are the fruits of what started  when the Romam Catholic Bishop of San Francisco and his compatriots in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints pushed through Prop. 8. It may now be time for the harvest.
The challenge is getting the little buggers to take the pills.  But tiny little condoms might be worth trying!
Garbage disposals are illegal in New York City?  Really? Residential or commercial or both?  I find that hard to believe.
@Jim: Did you read the article? Because it mentioned "sterilization products," which I think is what you mean by "infertility drugs."

Not only is it a misguided attempt; bread isn't even good for pigeons! Sure they'll eat it, just as kids will eat Twinkies. But few people think to put seed out for birds—which, I know, is bait for rats too.

I live near Tompkins Square Park, and I can't tell you how many people I've reprimanded for throwing out crusts on the sidewalk, and they've all replied, "I'm not feeding the rats; I'm feeding the pigeons [or squirrels.]" Parts of Tompkins look like a moonscape, they're so torn-up, and between the children whose playgrounds adjoin the rat areas and the red-tail hawks that have to be protected, you can't really use poison in the park.

I have coyotes in my backyard and in the field behind my house and I still have pack rats. I see the coyotes every morning as they head back to sleep through the day. Last year one of the rats even built a nest in a bait station and was hoarding the pellets. So I think rats are not a problem unique to an urban area. And before people get up and arms about the bait stations I’ve been told by my pest guy that ingesting a rat that ingested the poison does not harm the predator. I’m just trying to keep them at bay and out of my garage and house.

@aubrey: "east 52nd street northwest side from second avenue toward third, at least up to the hungarian embassy."

Google Street View shows sidewalk trash bags along there.[1] The city should prohibit sidewalk trash bags. They look like something you would see in a poverty-stricken, third-world country.

[1] https://goo.gl/maps/0VMpv
